title: Kathmandu shareholders back takeover of Rip Curl
text:
Shareholders in outdoor and camping retailer Kathmandu have overwhelmingly voted in favour of its $A350 million takeover of surf group Rip Curl at the extraordinary meeting in Sydney on Friday.

99.6 per cent of investors backed the deal.

Kathmandu's largest shareholder, Rod Duke's Briscoe Group, recently had his 19 per cent stake diluted down to 19.7 per cent after taking up some but not all of its entitlements in the recent $NZ145 million ($138 million) capital raising to fund the acquisition.

Briscoe, which made a failed takeover offer for Kathmandu in 2015, backed the take over.

The Rip Curl deal will almost double Kathmandu's revenues, creating a $NZ1 billion global outdoor and action sports company with operations in Australia, New Zealand, North America, Europe, south-east Asia and South America.

The combined group will have a footprint of 341 retail stores, 254 licensed stores and more than 7300 wholesale doors around the world.
description: Rip Curl is the last of the big three Aussie surf brands to be sold from their founders.
